text: Hafskael's Yard, nestled at the base of towering cliffs, stands as a testament to Bjornling craftsmanship and maritime prowess. Here, the master shipwright Hafskael oversees the construction of legendary longships, each vessel infused with the blessings of the Ruinous Powers. With the relentless sound of sawing and hammering echoing against the cliffs, this bustling shipyard serves as the beating heart of Bjornling naval might, where elite Huscarls gather to plan conquests and legendary expeditions

Perched atop a mountain peak lies the imposing seat of power of Harald Whyrlas, High Jarl of the Graeling Tribe. Towering even among Norscans, he rules from the Graeling Moot—a gathering of villages forming his domain. Unlike his counterparts who seek only the spoils of battle, Harald harbors a grand ambition—to unite all Norscan tribes under the Graeling Kingdom. Carved from mountain bedrock, his colossal throne, adorned with the skulls of vanquished chieftains, symbolizes his dominance and his vision for a unified realm

Nestled in the heart of Troll Country lies the vast expanse of the Kalti Delta marshes—a perilous realm where danger lurks at every turn. Here, salt and freshwater marshes merge, creating a treacherous labyrinth of terrain. Men shun these deadly marshlands, where perilous elements and ferocious beasts abound. Yet, the Sarl have mastered these waters, utilizing their longships to navigate with skill and harvesting resources for shipbuilding and troll hunting, demonstrating their courage and resilience in the face of relentless danger.

Amidst the frozen expanse of the Aesling territory, the Monolith of Valmir Aesling stands as a grim testament to the tribe's ferocity. Devoted to the Blood God Khorne, the Aesling are known for their insatiable battle lust. Once a lieutenant of the Everchosen Asavar Kul, Valmir Aesling's legend persists. The monolith, a place of worship and slaughter, sees berserkers clash in ritual combat, seeking Khorne's favor. It stands as a conduit to the divine, where mortal and Chaos realms intertwine in endless carnage—a shrine to the Aesling's relentless pursuit of glory.

Near the Volary lies the vast steppe plain known as the Great Gathering—a desolate expanse where Kurgan tribes converge. Stretching beyond the horizon, it teems with countless tents of various sizes, a temporary home for nomadic warriors. Here, amidst the endless plains, Kurgan tribes assemble before embarking on migrations deeper into the steppes or launching pillaging conquests into distant Cathay. Yet, amidst the camaraderie, danger lurks, for the Great Gathering is also a battleground where rival zars engage in constant outbreaks of fighting and dueling, shaping the fate of tribes with each clash.

In desolate Norsca, Vinnskor's shattered remnants speak of Aesling savagery. Once bustling, now silent streets bear witness to past brutality. At dawn, farmers tended fields and women fetched water. Now, only wind disturbs abandoned lanes, carrying blood’s scent. Scrawny thralls toil, watched by axe-bearing warriors. Blood stains the ground, a testament to Aesling’s fury and Khorne's favor. Yet amidst ruins, Einarr Sigdansson vows to reclaim home. Vinnskor, despite the chaos, stands as a beacon—a place to reclaim Baersonlings' legacy.

Amidst the eastern steppes, within the sprawling Yusak Encampment, lies the opulent tent of Zar Sargath, devoted high chieftain of the Yusak tribe and fervent worshiper of Slaanesh, the Prince of Pleasure. Adorned with jewels and draped in fragrant offerings to the god of excess, Sargath's tent stands as a decadent shrine to Slaanesh within the heart of the encampment. Here, amidst the indulgence of wine and lavish trinkets, Sargath revels in the hedonistic pleasures that define his devotion to the Dark Prince.

In the icy realm of Albion, the Icefang Monolith stands tall—a massive pillar of ice inscribed with chaotic runes. A focal point for those drawn by the legendary Greataxe, it shapes the surrounding ice into living guardians. For the Icefang tribe, it epitomizes unrivaled strength, revered and fiercely defended against all challengers. Yet, they clash endlessly with Albion's enigmatic inhabitants for control over the glacial tower. In the frozen heart of Albion, amidst relentless blizzards, the Icefang Monolith looms—a mysterious and potent force that calls forth only the most daring to its icy domain.

In the heart of the desert of Khemri stands the once-proud pyramid, now corrupted by chaos, a testament to the conquest of Surtha Ek, Chariot Lord of the Varg. Renowned for his unparalleled skill on the chariot, Surtha Ek's prowess rivals even that of Settra the Imperishable himself. As Surtha Ek crossed continents and sacked the pyramid, he settled a feud that spanned worlds, asserting the dominance of the Varg even in the unforgiving sands of Khemri. Now, chaos marks adorn the rubble of the great pyramid, a chilling reminder of the Varg's unrelenting might and the chaos that now reigns in Khemri.

High above the chasm-marked cliffs Horvenghaast, flat circles  ring with steel and screams. Here, warriors duel beneath the gaze of Khorne — not for coin, but for honour, blood, and ascent. These sacred fighting circles draw Norscans, Skaelings, and even exiled champions seeking favour through death. The blood spilled in these rooftop rites feeds the stones and marks the strongest with Khorne’s favour.

Carved into blood-slick mountain rock, the Hall of the Snaegr is a fortress-temple to violence. Its walls echo with war chants, and the skulls of conquered foes line its gore-drenched galleries. Here, the warriors of the Snaegr offer blood to Urlfdaemonkin, and the Moon-time of Ulf is awaited like a second birth. Only the strongest survive the trials within. The weak feed the flame — or the warriors.

At the foot of the cliffs, where tides rise and retreat like the breath of a drowned god, lies the Seafarers’ Shrine — an ancient, barnacle-clad sea cave echoing with half-forgotten prayers. At high tide, waist-deep waters flood its hollow, while at low tide, pilgrims tread carefully across jagged stone to kneel in brine and gloom. Here the Norse pay homage to a dozen fickle sea spirits — many adopted from foreign tongues — in the hope one might answer when death looms on the waves.
The blood moon rises. Bones twist. Rage burns. I hear Urlfdaemonkin’s voice in my veins.
Passive Ability: "Moon-Time of Urlf" for Werekin Champions
I feel his teeth beneath the waves, guiding my prow. He is with me.
Passive Ability: "Mark of Mermedus" when fighting at sea
I’ve bled on the clifftops of Horvenghaast — I’ll bleed you just the same.
They speared the wolves of Huern, and now turn their sharpened wrath upon larger beasts still.
Passive Ability: "Wolfsbane Brotherhood" for Marauder Spearmen units

Beneath the misty hills of Bragnir lie the barrows of long-dead kings — stoic Bjornling chieftains entombed in stone and saga.Their deeds echo in the songs of skalds, for it is here that the greatest tales are forged and passed down. Pilgrims and poets alike wander these ridges, seeking the weight of legacy beneath the turf. In the valleys below, where kelp-fed soil yields rare bounty, life blossoms among the dead.

Battered by fog and storm, the coasts of Albion yield few secrets — save for one. High on a lonely bluff stands the tomb of Erik the Lost, greatest of Norse explorers, who met his end charting the unknowable. Shrouded in mist and legend alike, the site draws bold pilgrims and curious captains, each seeking his legacy or blessing. Those who find it speak of dreams filled with stormlight, sea-spirits… and the call to voyage ever farther.
